children.subject: You could always add the class on Piazza for Spring 2019 and check out the HWs and Discussions yourself

history.content:
i am currently taking the class, and highly recommend it. The prerequisite is just CS70; knowledge of CS170 is not presumed but the experience with proofs and run time will help a lot in the class. The textbook is Katz and Lindells' Intro to Modern Cryptography.

Hopefully the professor won't mind me pasting the syllabus here:

 

 
DateTopicKL ChaptersHomeworks
11/22/19Introduction and overview. Private-key cryptography. The syntax of private-key encryption. The shift cipher. 1.1-1.3hw1 release 01/23
21/24/19Elementary cryptanalysis and frequency analysis. Principles of Modern Cryptography1.3 and 1.4 
31/29/19Modern cryptography: definitions, assumptions, and proofs. Perfect secrecy. The one-time pad. Limitations of perfect secrecy. A computational notion of security. Pseudorandomness and pseudorandom generators.2.1-2.3, 3.1, 3.2.1, and 3.3.1hw1 due, hw2 release 01/30
41/31/19Pseudorandom generators and stream ciphers. The pseudo-OTP. Proofs by reduction, and a proof of security for the pseudo-OTP. 3.3 
52/5/19Security for multiple encryptions. Drawbacks of deterministic encryption. Chosen-plaintext attacks and CPA-security. Pseudorandom Functions3.4 and 3.5.1hw2 due, hw3 release 02/06
62/7/19CPA-security from stream ciphers and block ciphers. 3.5  
72/12/19Encrypting arbitrary-length messages: block-cipher modes of operation.3.6hw3 due 02/13
82/14/19Chosen-ciphertext attacks (and review).3.7 
92/19/19Midterm I : Exam Location Soda-310 hw4 release 02/20
102/21/19Message integrity and message authentication codes (MACs). Defining security for MACs. Constructing MACs. 4.1, 4.2, and 4.3 
112/26/19CBC-MAC. Authenticated encryption and generic constructions.4.4.1, 4.5.1, and 4.5.2 (no proof)hw4 due, hw5 release 02/27
122/28/19Secure sessions. CCA-security. Hash functions and collision resistance.

4.5.3, 4.5.4, 5.1.1 and 5.3.1

 
133/5/19Birthday attacks on hash functions. Additional applications of hash functions.5.4.1, and 5.6.1-5.6.3hw5 due, hw6 release 03/06
143/7/19One-Way Functions and Implications7.1,7.2,7.3.1, 7.4,7.5, 7.7 (read on your own) 
153/12/19Practical constructions of stream ciphers. 6.1.1-6.1.4hw6 due 03/13
163/14/19Practical constructions of block ciphers. Substitution-permutation networks (SPNs).6.2.1 
173/19/19Fiestel Networks. The data encryption standard (DES).6.2.2, 6.2.3, and 6.2.4. 
183/21/19Midterm II : Exam Location Soda-310  
-3/26/19Spring Break  
-3/28/19Spring Break  
194/2/19Group theory. Cyclic groups. Hardness assumptions in cyclic groups: the discrete-logarithm assumption and Diffie-Hellman problems. Concrete Parameters. 8.1.3, 8.3.1-8.3.3, 9.3hw7 release 04/03
204/4/19Drawbacks of private-key cryptography. The Diffie-Hellman key-exchange protocol and the public-key setting. Public-key encryption: syntax and definitions of security. El Gamal encryption.  10.1, 10.3, 10.4, and 11.1 
214/9/19Definitions of security for public-key encryption. Hybrid encryption and the KEM/DEM paradigm. El Gamal encryption. 11.2 (skip proof of Theorem 11.6), 11.3 (skip proof of Theorem 11.12), 11.4.1, 11.4.2, and 11.4.4 (only the discussion that El Gamal encryption is malleable).  hw7 due, hw8 release 04/10
224/11/19Digital signatures. The hash-and-sign paradigm. Schnorr Signature Scheme. Certificates and public-key infrastructures. 12.1-12.3, 12.5.1 and 12.7 
234/16/19Special Topic I: Identity Based Encryptionpaper (Sec 1-4.1)hw8 due, hw9 release 04/17
244/18/19Special Topic I: Identity Based Encryption 
254/23/19Special Topic II: Zero-Knowledge Proofsnotes (Sec 4.1-4.3)hw9 due, hw10 release 04/24
264/25/19Special Topic II: Zero-Knowledge Proofs  
274/30/19Special Topic II: Zero-Knowledge Proofs hw10 due 05/01
285/2/19Special Topic III: Cryptocurrency  
-5/13/19Final : 11:30A - 2:30P | Exam Location: 251 Hearst Gym

What does the course cover and are there any prereqs?

Thanks!
